Admiral Tyrwhitt telegraphed on 25th Hay seeking a ruling as regards his powers. He alluded to the Standing Instructions from H.M, Government contained in Admiralty telegrams Mo.812 - 815, to Foreign Office telegram to Peking, No.568 of 5th Octetor, 1927, and to Admiralty telegram No,510 and from these he evidently inferred that he had authority to move troops from Shanghai and to replace them from Hong Kong. This authority, he stated, has al?rays "been, and is still being questioned by the Generel Officers Commanding in China. Adm5.ralty replied to Admiral Tyrwhitt (Telegram Mo.788 of 29th May, 1923), informing him that Admiralty telegrams 543 and 812 - 315 set forth the authority and powers confided to him by H.M. Government and that Foreign Office Telegram 568 must not be construed as extending these powers. . The position now is, therefore, that Commander - in-Chief, China, remains the Principal Military Adviser of H.M.
